para.paratext: O.C.G.A. § 24-8-801(d)(1) follows the federal rule and excludes from the hearsay rule any prior out-of-court statement of a declarant if the declarant testifies at the trial or hearing, is subject to cross-examination concerning the statement, and the statement is admissible as a prior inconsistent statement or a prior consistent statement under O.C.G.A. § 24-6-613[1] or is otherwise admissible.

A prior consistent videotaped statement was admissible at trial where the witness testified and was available for cross-examination, and defendant implied through cross-examination of the witness that he had a motive to testify in exchange for a favorable plea deal with the state.[2]

A prior inconsistent statement is inadmissible in the absence of an opportunity for effective cross-examination of the declarant.[3] However, when a witness admits making a prior inconsistent statement, evidence of that statement is admissible because the jury may consider the inconsistent statements as substantive evidence as well as for impeachment purposes.[4] In Thompson v. State,[5] the Georgia Supreme Court allowed portions of a taped conversation with police to be played for the jury where the witness had conveniently forgotten incriminating statements she made regarding the defendant.

If a prior written inconsistent statement is used for impeachment, the witness must have an opportunity to respond before the statement is admitted into evidence.[6] However, the proffering party does not have to show it to the witness during the examination.[7] Upon request, the proffering party has to disclose the statement to opposing counsel.

Prior inconsistent statements cannot be introduced through extrinsic evidence if they are irrelevant or collateral to the subject matter of the case.[8] Thus, a victim's resignation from her employment where she admitted to taking liberties with her employee discount was irrelevant to the defendant's case for robbery and was therefore inadmissible.

Generally, prior consistent statements of a testifying witness will not be admissible[9] because such testimony is cumulative and an improper method to bolster the witness's credibility.[10] However, a prior consistent statement may assist a witness who lacks memory of details included in a prior statement.[11] For example, in Manning v. State,[12] the testifying witness was unable to remember details about a car that he saw near a murder scene. The state called the police officer to testify about the prior statement that the witness gave to him on the day of the crime, which contained the details that linked the car to the defendant. In Mosley v. State,[13] the prior consistent statements of a witness were admitted where, although the witness was available to testify, the witness was reluctant to do so and basically denied any recollection of the facts.

Under O.C.G.A. § 24-6-612, if a writing is used to refresh the recollection of a witness on the stand, opposing counsel has the right in both civil and criminal cases to question the witness and to introduce portions that relate to the witness' testimony.

Prior consistent statements may also be admitted to rebut an attack on a witness's credibility. According to Woodard v. State,[14] a witness's prior consistent statements will be admissible if (1) the veracity of the witness' trial testimony has been placed in issue at trial, (2) the witness is present at trial, and (3) the witness is available for cross-examination. Following Woodard, the Georgia Court of Appeals further explained:

[O]nly if affirmative charges of recent fabrication, improper influence, or improper motive are raised during cross-examination is a witness's veracity placed in issue so as to permit the introduction of a prior consistent statement. Even then, the prior consistent statement may be admitted as nonhearsay only if it was made before the motive or influence came into existence or before the time of the alleged recent fabrication. Otherwise, it is pure hearsay, which cannot be admitted merely to bolster the witness's credibility.[15]

Georgia courts have inconsistently determined when the veracity of a witnesses trial testimony is “in issue,” but the trend has been toward admitting prior consistent statements if there is a specific charge of recent fabrication, improper motive or influence made in regards to the testimony,[16] which is more in line with federal practice and the Georgia Supreme Court's holding in Woodard.[17] Additionally, courts have required that the statement “predate the alleged fabrication, influence, or motive.”[18] In Edwards v. State,[19] the trial court allowed the state to read to a witness, in the presence of the jury, a statement which he had given to police. The Georgia Supreme Court held that the statement was properly admitted because the veracity of the witness was at issue, but a dissenting justice argued: “The only difference [between this case and [Cuzzort] is that this case is worse if possible. No one has challenged the witness' sworn testimony as being contradictory to the statement he gave to the police. Under this logic, if a witness gives a statement to 10 different police officers and none of the statements contradict each other or his sworn testimony, then a party may read the 10 different statements to prove that the witness told the truth on the witness stand.”[20] The Georgia Court of Appeals upheld the trial court's decision in Brannon v. State,[21] a child molestation case, to admit testimony from a victim's mother about statements made by the child. The child testified, and her veracity was not challenged. The court's holding in Cuzzort has been taken to an extreme in child molestation cases,[22] which have required that the child be a sworn witness and subject to cross-examination.

O.C.G.A. § 24-6-613(c) states that a prior consistent statement is admissible to rehabilitate a witness if the prior consistent statement logically rebuts an attack made on the witness's credibility, i.e., recent fabrication, improper influence, or motive. A general attack on credibility (such as an attack on the witness's character or prior criminal conviction) is insufficient to authorize rehabilitation, though. To be admissible, the prior consistent statement must have been made before the alleged recent fabrication, improper influence, or motive arose.
Bolling v. State, 300 Ga. 694, 797 S.E.2d 872 (2017); see also Mosley v. State, 298 Ga. 849, 785 S.E.2d 297 (2016).

Soto v. State, 285 Ga. 367, 677 S.E.2d 95 (2009) (out-of-court statement by coconspirator inadmissible because the defendant did not have an opportunity to cross-examine the declarant). Anthony v. State, 303 Ga. 399, 811 S.E.2d 399 (2018). Where police detective was able to testify to declarant's statement, as a prior inconsistent statement, where at trial, declarant denied ever having the conversation with Defendant.
American Management Services East, LLC v. Fort Benning Family Communities, LLC, 333 Ga. App. 664, 774 S.E.2d 233 (2015).
Thompson v. State, 304 Ga. 146, 816 S.E.2d 646 (2018).
Daniels v. State, 349 Ga. App. 681, 824 S.E.2d 754 (2019).
Woodard v. State, 269 Ga. 317, 496 S.E.2d 896, 71 A.L.R.5th 787 (1998) (overruled on other grounds by, Bunn v. State, 291 Ga. 183, 728 S.E.2d 569 (2012)).

See Forde v. State, 289 Ga. App. 805, 658 S.E.2d 410 (2008) (videotaped interview of abused child was not admissible as prior consistent statement, but was hearsay that could not be admitted to bolster victim's credibility).

Gardiner v. State, 252 Ga. 422, 424–425, 314 S.E.2d 202 (1984) (disapproved of on other grounds by, Duckworth v. State, 268 Ga. 566, 492 S.E.2d 201 (1997)); Manning v. State, 273 Ga. 744, 545 S.E.2d 914 (2001).
Manning v. State, 273 Ga. 744, 545 S.E.2d 914 (2001).
Woodard v. State, 269 Ga. 317, 320, 496 S.E.2d 896, 71 A.L.R.5th 787 (1998) (overruled on other grounds by, Bunn v. State, 291 Ga. 183, 728 S.E.2d 569 (2012)).
Phillips v. State, 241 Ga. App. 764, 766, 527 S.E.2d 604 (2000).
Phillips v. State, 241 Ga. App. 764, 527 S.E.2d 604 (2000); Baugh v. State, 276 Ga. 736, 585 S.E.2d 616 (2003); Forde v. State, 289 Ga. App. 805, 658 S.E.2d 410 (2008).

“Consistent with Fed. R. Evid. 801(d)(1)(B), a witness's veracity is placed in issue so as to permit the introduction of a prior consistent statement only if affirmative charges of recent fabrication, improper influence, or improper motive are raised during cross examination.” Woodard v. State, 269 Ga. 317, 320, 496 S.E.2d 896, 71 A.L.R.5th 787 (1998) (overruled on other grounds by, Bunn v. State, 291 Ga. 183, 728 S.E.2d 569 (2012)).

See also Duggan v. State, 285 Ga. 363, 366, 677 S.E.2d 92 (2009); Cash v. State, 294 Ga. App. 741, 669 S.E.2d 731 (2008); Nguyen v. State, 294 Ga. App. 67, 668 S.E.2d 514 (2008); Broner v. State, 284 Ga. 402, 667 S.E.2d 613 (2008).
Trial court erred by admitting prior consistent statement because there was no challenge to the veracity of witness' trial testimony. Character v. State, 285 Ga. 112, 674 S.E.2d 280 (2009).

Victim's pretrial statements inadmissible as prior consistent statements because the statements were made after the alleged motive for false testimony came into existence. Connelly v. State, 295 Ga. App. 765, 673 S.E.2d 274 (2009).
Edwards v. State, 255 Ga. 149, 335 S.E.2d 869 (1985).

See also Lumpkin v. State, 255 Ga. 363, 338 S.E.2d 431 (1986) (overruled by, Woodard v. State, 269 Ga. 317, 496 S.E.2d 896, 71 A.L.R.5th 787 (1998)); Richardson v. State, 256 Ga. 746, 353 S.E.2d 342 (1987).
Edwards v. State, 255 Ga. 149, 150, 335 S.E.2d 869 (1985) (Smith, J. dissenting).
Brannon v. State, 176 Ga. App. 781, 337 S.E.2d 782 (1985).

See, e.g., Patterson v. State, 180 Ga. App. 194, 348 S.E.2d 578 (1986); Runion v. State, 180 Ga. App. 440, 349 S.E.2d 288 (1986). But see Cash v. State, 294 Ga. App. 741, 669 S.E.2d 731 (2008) (noting that a prior consistent statement may be introduced only if the prior statement was made before the alleged motive or influence came into existence); Nguyen v. State, 294 Ga. App. 67, 668 S.E.2d 514 (2008) (allowing prior consistent statement of victim because defense counsel implied during cross examination that victim had recently fabricated her trial testimony to reunite with her mother).
